info.game_comments: (Sarah: What was our rival in the Space Race up to all those years?  Clues from Russia's Cosmonaut Training Centre, next on Jeopardy!)

double_jeopardy_round: THE VATICAN'S INDEX OF FORBIDDEN BOOKS

(1, 1).clue: Ian Fleming based this character in part on Cary Grant, who later turned down the role

(2, 1).clue: In the 1770s she lived on Arch Street in Philly, where she & husband John ran an upholstery business

(3, 1).clue: Lewisite, an arsenic-containing blistering agent, was developed to be used in this conflict

(4, 1).clue: Though lace can be made of many types of thread, this flaxen fiber is historically the source of the finest

(5, 1).clue: At many Japanese hotels, guests enjoy cha-no-yu, the ceremony celebrating this, perhaps in late afternoon

(6, 1).clue: This Christmas carol's 2nd line begins, "Above thy deep and dreamless sleep, the silent stars go by"

(1, 2).clue: In 1922 Grant worked as a stiltworker advertising Steeplechase Park at this Brooklyn attraction

(2, 2).clue: On Market Street, between 5th & 6th, you can see this, which bears an inscription from Leviticus 25:10

(3, 2).clue: Millions in Asia are at risk from high arsenic levels in this: the EPA's new limit is 10 parts per billion

(4, 2).clue: The 2 basic types of lace are bobbin & this one, also a type of embroidery

(5, 2).clue: Before holidaying in potentially dangerous places, visit this U.S. govt. department's "Travel Warnings" website

(6, 2).clue: The building housing local administration offices that are also used for public meetings

(1, 3).clue: Until he was dubbed Cary Grant by Paramount Studios, Cary was known by this name

(2, 3).clue: In 1774 this assembly met for the first time in Carpenters' Hall in Philadelphia

(3, 3).clue: A case of arsenic poisoning is deftly solved in this author's 1932 story "The Tuesday Night Club"

(4, 3).clue: In Elizabethan times, lace was a popular material for this stiff, frilly collar

(5, 3).clue: On a visit to this country, check out the Suceava monasteries & also take in a Transylvanian village or two

(6, 3).clue: This term for one who frequents fashionable spots was the title of Walter Winchell's column

(1, 4).clue: Cary turned down roles opposite this leading lady in "Roman Holiday" & "Sabrina" but did act with her in "Charade"

(2, 4).clue: The city's motto, "Philadelphia maneto", means "Let" this "continue"

(3, 4).clue: The mineral arsenopyrite, mainly arsenic, sulfur & this element, smells of garlic on being fractured

(4, 4).clue: This English monarch loved to wear lace, & an herb with tiny white flowers is called her "lace"

(5, 4).clue: On a holiday to the east coast of this state, you can see the Pepsi 400 & the Saturn V

(6, 4).clue: Equal to 36 square miles, it's a subdivision of a county

(1, 5).clue: Cary's only child is Jennifer Grant, whose mother is this actress often seen courtside at L.A. Lakers games

(2, 5).clue: This institute established in 1824 is Philadelphia's Museum of Science & Technology

(3, 5).clue: In the 1890s mildew plus an arsenic compound called Paris Green in this decorative material killed thousands

(4, 5).clue: "Gros point de" this city, Italy's greatest lace center, arose in the 1600s with elaborate scroll patterns

(5, 5).clue: If you travel to Morocco, "come with me to" the Berber castles known as these

(6, 5).clue: Named for the PM who sponsored them, these 1767 "Acts" levied unpopular taxes on the American colonies

(1, 1).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from Star City, Russia.)  This Russian capsule can ferry up to three crew members to and from the International Space Station

(2, 1).clue: From 1934 until 1939, it was known as the Augusta National Invitation Tournament

(3, 1).clue: Contrary to popular belief, this largest desert is only 30% sand; 70% is gravelly plains & rocky plateaus

(4, 1).clue: It must have made this author miserable to know his "Hunchback of Notre Dame" was included

(5, 1).clue: Located in this city's Russian Hill section, Lombard Street has been called the world's crookedest street

(6, 1).clue: A personal record of events in someone's life

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Star City, Russia.)  Behind me is a simulator of this craft that was inhabited by 104 people during its 15 years in space

(2, 2).clue: Held in Hawaii, it consists of a 2.4-mile ocean swim, a 112-mile bike race & a 26.2-mile run

(3, 2).clue: The world's largest unbroken expanse of sand is the Rub Al-Khali, or "Empty Quarter", of this desert

(4, 2).clue: There was no monkeying around when this man's "History of the Decline & Fall of the Roman Empire" made the list

(5, 2).clue: This east-west Interstate through Nebraska isn't really endless; it's exactly 455.32 miles

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Star City, Russia.) One of the cosmonauts honored at Star City is this amateur parachutist, who in 1963 became the first woman in space

(2, 3).clue: Among those who took part in this event's 150th Jubilee in 2001 were Juan Carlos, Prince Philip & Dennis Conner

(3, 3).clue: Botswana's Okavango Swamp is a remnant of an inland sea that once covered this desert

(4, 3).clue: Somehow his "Critique of Pure Reason" made the list, but not his "Critique of Practical Reason"

(5, 3).clue: In Boston, Mass. Ave., Massachusetts Avenue, intersects Com. Ave., this street

(1, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from Star City, Russia.)  In 1961, Yuri Gagarin became the first man in space & flew three times faster than anyone else had in a capsule called this, or East

(2, 4).clue: It's a long day's journey into night in this event held each June on the Circuit de la Sarthe in France

(3, 4).clue: This Middle Eastern desert's name is from the Hebrew for "to dry"

(4, 4).clue: We must confess, both this Frenchman's "Emile" & "The Social Contract" are listed

(5, 4).clue: L.A.'s Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Parkway runs in front of what was this hotel, home to the Cocoanut Grove

(1, 5).clue: Seen here is Buran, the U.S.S.R.'s answer to this U.S. program that got off the ground in 1981

(2, 5).clue: The "All Star Game of Thoroughbred Racing", & racing's richest event, it's held each fall at a different track

(3, 5).clue: Subdivisions of this desert include the Ka-Shun, Dzungarian & Trans-Altai

(4, 5).clue: "Madame Bovary" by Flaubert, we understand, but "Principles of Political Economy" by this 3-named Brit, we don't

(5, 5).clue: Named for a president, it was the USA's first transcontinental road for cars

(0, 0).clue: It's the only surname ever shared by a U.S. president & a British prime minister
